data.formatted_address: 62 Ping Jiang Dao, He Xi Qu, China, 300061
data.name: Tianjin Museum

reviews.text: Tianjin Museum is by far the largest museum of such kind in China. It is more than hundred years old as it started its journey in 1908. The museum is five storied, plus one basement. It has a cafetaria, as well as a nice souvenir shop. The middle area, where there is a staircase, is huge and gives a bold public character to the building. There is a huge courtyard in front of the museum. It now houses relucs, artworks, artifacts to show the rich culture, heritage and history of Tianjin region.

Not a lot of stuff, but definitely worth a visit if you're in the area, especially since it's free. Go on a weekend, they'll have more services available then. Beautiful architecture. Don't forget to go to the art museum next to it! Some great works on display, especially oil paintings by Wang on the second floor.
Tianjin Museum is a master piece architecture to visit. Specially the atrium  of the museum is remarkable and outstanding. Must visit place in Tianjin.
Really good place to learn about Tianjin historical culture. Entrance fee was free so that's another good thing ABT it
The museum itself is just alright, but the whole street is lined with galleries and libraries which can easily take up half of your day.  So it's a good place to visit.

data.formatted_address: Hebei District, China, 300141
data.name: 天津之眼

reviews.text: Very beautiful especially at night. It is supposed to be the biggest Ferris wheel over the bridge in the whole world.  It costs $10 USD to take it.  It moves slowly and you can see nearby landscapes once above. The waiting line is very short off season.  The ride takes 45 minutes.   It looks a lot nicer at night than during the day.
Beautiful at night, lots of activities while walking towards the ferris wheel

I visited this giant wheel during my weekend trip to Tianjin. You have to buy a ticket costing 70 Yuan for one trip. The wheel keeps on rotating with slow speed all the time and you need to get in quickly. It takes around 30 to 45 mins for one round. The city view from the top of the wheel is spectacular. Overall design and location of this world's 4th largest wheel is a true masterpiece. The wheel design is like an inverted bicycle wheel. In the evening you can see a pink colored image of the giant wheel in the river from bridge when whole of the Tianjin is illuminated with luminaries.

It was winter 2012, weather is cold and everything is almost frozen.  had a great view up there looking down at the frozen river.
Tickets are more expensive for passport holders (aka foreigners).  Can't remember how much i paid, but it is a nice place to have the bird view of Tianjin.

Construction started 2007 and completed the main body December 18, 2007 and wheel opened for public April 7, 2008. It is 120 metre tall gaint. It called Tianjin Eye and also called "The Tientin Eye". It is electrically powered and has 48 passenger capsules & each capsule able to carry 8 passengers. It takes 30 minutes to a complete rotation.

reviews.text: It is called “Niang Niang Gong” by local people.  It was a place wheee people pray for safe travels especially on water.  Then it transformed into a praying place for all sorts of worldly wishes.  Now it is more like a museum of historical artifacts and a live praying place.  It is in a wonderful location where many local art stores are surrounding it and close to the biggest river of the city.  A must visit for anyone coming to Tianjin.

A beautiful temple complex, typical though. There's also a gift/souvenir shop and a small kind of museum in the premises. All in all, if you like temples, you can spend a nice 1 hour wandering around the halls and marveling at the statues and architecture.

The Tianjin Confucian Temple was built in the first year of Zhengtong in the Ming Dynasty (1436). It was a place for official learning and worship of Confucius in Tianjin during the Ming and Qing dynasties. Located on Dongmenli Street, Nankai District. The building is currently a cultural relic protection unit in Tianjin. It is also the largest and best-preserved ancient building complex in Tianjin. It is now the Tianjin Confucian Temple Museum.

The floor tiles inside the building are old and damaged, but it still retains its traditional and classic value. Reading the famous quotes of the Analects of Confucius and revisiting the example of education without discrimination is still worth the price!

reviews.text: I visited here 5 years ago. An old Soviet Air Craft Carrier is built as a museum, where you have chance to see how a giant ship look like. The Chinese government bought it for the purpose of building a museum, but they did not. They use it to duplicate a real warship, a real Aircraft carrier, Liaoning.

It's like Russia but in China! Good and entertaining water action show and the action car show with excellent performers. There are dance shows and a parade as well. The price of admission is about 220rmb(about 34 USD) per person. Some say it's a bit pricey but you get the water show, car show, dance show, a parade, the aircraft carrier tour and get to hang out in a nice Russia inspired town with lots of food to choose from. I think it's worth the trip if you happen to be in the TEDA/Tianjin area.

reviews.text: We had a great morning at the museum. My favourite by far was the ‘team’ marble run. In order to make the ball move across the wall a child needs to stand at each lever. The kids got so into their rolls they were exhausted spinning the levers. The whole museum had great Interactive exhibits teaching the kids basic scientific principles. It’s not flashy, but really a worthwhile morning spent with my three kids and we’ll be able to discuss these experiences for years to come.
Not much English aside from exhibit titles, but a fun way to beat the afternoon heat!

Tianjin Science and Technology Museum was founded in 1992. The first phase of the project was completed in September 1994. It was officially opened to the public on New Year's Day in 1995. The name of the museum was inscribed by the then General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee and President Jiang Zemin and the late famous mathematician Chen Shengshen. He served as the honorary curator.

reviews.text: As this is only the 4th highest skyscraper in Tianjin and a distance from city center/concessions area attractions, come here if only if you have many days in the city. The most unique parts of Tianjin's urban area are elsewhere, in the 9-nations concessions area where settlers from 10 countries gathered in various neighborhoods & left their original architecture behind. This TV tower is near Power Town Mall (by the west-entrance of this lake) which has an 1800's era atmosphere underground and AoCheng, a bar hopping district nearby for evening activities.

The Tianjin Radio and Television Tower is a 415,22 m -talltower in Tianjin, China used primarily for communication. It is the 8th tallest freestanding tower in the world. It was built in 1991 at a cost of $45 million. Approximately two-thirds of the way up the tower is an observation pod with 253 square meters (2,720 sq ft) of floor space (used mostly for communication equipment). It is a member of the World Federation of Great Towers.

The Italian Style Street is only a short walk south of the Jianguodao Station (建国道). Note that the European style buildings are historical buildings built by the colonial powers during the late Qing dynasty. Most of the European style buildings today are converted into western restaurants, bars, and boutique shops. A must see when coming to China for the interesting contrast between Italian and Chinese design.

reviews.text: Wow! This hotel is truly exceptional! From the moment I stepped foot in the lobby, I was blown away by the level of hospitality and service provided. The staff went above and beyond to ensure that my stay was nothing short of extraordinary. The attention to detail and personal touch made me feel like a valued guest. The amenities were top-notch, and the rooms were beautifully designed and comfortable. I can confidently say that this is the best hotel I've ever been to. If you're looking for an unforgettable experience, I highly recommend staying here!

I am deeply disappointed and shocked by my recent stay at The Ritz-Carlton, Tianjin. During my visit, I encountered a series of disturbing events that I believe reflect poorly on the management and integrity of this establishment.

Firstly, I was verbally abused by the front desk staff and subsequently threatened by a manager who even suggested calling the police, which ultimately led nowhere. This response was not only unprofessional but also made me feel unsafe and unwelcome.

Furthermore, the housekeeping staff entered my room without permission and stole my iPhone SE. To make matters worse, the hotel falsely accused me of damaging the phone and the bathtub. As a result, I was charged an additional $500, which is completely unjustified and feels like a deliberate attempt to exploit me.

I expected a much higher standard of service from a prestigious brand like The Ritz-Carlton. This experience has not only caused me financial loss but also significant distress. I strongly urge potential guests to reconsider their stay at this location unless the hotel management addresses these serious issues and ensures that such incidents never happen to another guest.

data.formatted_address: China, Tian Jin Shi, He Ping Qu, 张自忠路158号 邮政编码: 300041

reviews.text:
The hotel is very good for Elite members… I was upgraded to suite even before arriving. I think their gesture is nice. I was Platinum Elite upon check in.

But their ground crew at the lobby & lounge could be friendlier. The lady at the lounge was quite snobbish for whatever reasons. I just checked in and asked what time does happy hour starts she gave an annoying look an responded you can’t start first, maybe later (it was maybe 10 minutes to it). Sometimes it’s the tone that changes the entire message, respond with a more PR friendly reply… not everyone is here “for free flow stuff”. I was just super tired after the journey from Beijing and wanted a drink. I didn’t bother about the food anyway.

The turn off part was my room door was left unlocked for 3-4 hours when I asked for turn down. I went out around 5pm & got back about 9pm+ so it was open for that long!!with the lash holding my room door open…

Anyway, I made a fuss because this should not be the case. I won’t know if anyone had gone in to install cameras or put poison into my water. Just saying. But it’s a security breach to leave your guest door open. And this is St Regis!!!

Initially they did not want to do anything but I forced them to look at the security cameras which they took until next morning coz it was already late. They didn’t even arrange anyone to explain the situation after checking until I asked at the check out counter.

Subsequently they wanted to brush it off with 2000 points but I insisted for an adequate amount of compensation. This is not a small matter but a huge one… I trusted the hotel but this is the drama caused…

Very much later we were then offered a day’s accommodation in form of points which I had accepted.

I hope this is a lesson for them to learn as this should never happen in St Regis. Or any Marriott brands. I mean, never. Not even maybe.

Room and location otherwise is very good. Breakfast selection is limited but sufficient. I would still return to the hotel.

Should have given 5 stars if the breakfast has more varieties. I would say breakfast range is disappointing given that it's such a great hotel.

Butler service is good. Room is big. Bed is very comfy and I had good sleep during my stay there

The gym is really well hidden. It's like walking a maze to reach. Swimming pool is just next to the gym room.

Going back Tianjin in 2 weeks time. But will be staying in Ritz Carlton.

The view from my room give me half city half river views which is good.

Excellent service with a personal touch. I received a written note from one of the staff (can't remember his name) with recommendations on suggested photography locations when I mentioned to him I was a photographer. Quite simply this was awesome personal touch beyond a normal service you who expect from a hotel staff. As usual, the room is luxurious room and I was lucky to have an unblocked view of the river front.

A lot going for this hotel:
1. Fantastic rooms - decent-sized esp corner rooms which are bigger, clean and comfy
2. Breakfast spread is good.
3. Excellent service
4. Good location - cross the road to the mall for more choices of food; walkable distance to the train station

data.name: Memorial to Zhou Enlai and Deng Yingchao

reviews.text: Free admission and you can experience the 1:1 Zhongnanhai Chinese Prime Minister office and residence in Beijing here!
Fresh experience about an important person for China in last century.
Respect

Adjacent to Tianjin Water Park. Admission was free, but please be sure to bring your ID (passport for foreigners) as you will need it. If you show your passport at the service center to the left of the entrance gate, you will be issued an admission ticket.
I visited on a Sunday afternoon, so there weren't many people in the museum, so I was able to take my time to look around. Information is provided in English as well as Chinese. Audio guides are available for rent at the entrance of the building, but we have not confirmed whether they are available in different languages. The inside of the museum is not very large, so we were able to tour it in about an hour. It is recommended that you learn the related history of former Prime Minister Chou Enlai before going.

Well worth a visit.

The Zhou Enlai and Deng Yingchao Memorial Hall is located in the Tianjin Water Park Scenic Area. It was built on February 28, 1998. It is a national patriotism education demonstration base, a national integrity education base and a national first-class museum.
The Zhou Enlai and Deng Yingchao Memorial Hall covers an area of ​​70,000 square meters, with a construction area of ​​13,000 square meters. The memorial hall is basically divided into three major exhibition areas, namely the main exhibition hall, the special exhibition hall of the Xihua Hall in Beijing Zhongnanhai built in a 1:1 scale, and the special aircraft exhibition hall.
The main exhibition hall contains: Zhou Enlai's life exhibition "People's Prime Minister Zhou Enlai", Deng Yingchao's special exhibition "Deng Yingchao - Pioneer of the Chinese Women's Movement in the 20th Century"; the special exhibition hall of the West Flower Hall has restored displays and the theme cultural relics exhibition "Great Feelings"; special aircraft display The hall displays the IL-14 special plane No. 678 presented to Premier Zhou Enlai by the Soviet government, which is a national second-class cultural relic.
In November 2017, he won the fifth national civilized unit honor. In December 2017, it was selected into the first batch of national research and practice education bases and camps for primary and secondary school students by the Ministry of Education.

data.name: Xihu Lake

reviews.text:
The Tianjin Water Park formerly known as "Green Dragon Pond" (青龙潭) prior to its official establishment. Its history can be traced back first century AD. Historically, the site was known for its lush vegetion and natural ecosystems, particular in summer and autumn.

With the establishment of Beiyang University and Nankai University at the turn of the 19th century, the waterways of the park became popular for swimming among academic staff and students during the hot summer months.

The ground-breaking for the Tianjin Water Park occurred on 26 August 1950 and it was officially opened July 1, 1951 to visitors.
Great place! Really nice for walking and watching local life. Free entry and lots of space to roam around! Best time to visit is around 6/7pm when people are out exercising and dancing after work.
Very nice and quiet location. The Hard Rock Cafe Tianjin is not far away and is worth a visit.

reviews.text: Simply historic.

It is a very Chinese-style place, where you can see old-style buildings and various Tianjin snacks. If you don’t mind not understanding their jokes, there are many cross talk performances to enjoy, and you can also go shopping for local antiques and jade. The overall feeling is that it has been tidied up, and the environment is clean. The only drawback is that there are many people on holidays, and the special snacks sometimes take a long time.
Shopping street, shopping street.

Tianjin's Ancient Culture Street is a street where you can see traditional Chinese culture and artwork, and is similar to Insa-dong in Korea.
However, you need to be careful when buying antiques as there are many fakes.
They sell fake watches and precious metals, but most of them can be purchased for about 1/10th of the asking price, so don't be fooled.
Bargaining must be done at a discount.
There's nothing I want to buy, but there are a lot of stores.

reviews.text: Not the easiest place to find and it’s in the middle of the highway… but it’s much better than I thought. There is a modern museum to explain the history of the forts and learn the history. And you can find the ruins of the forts at the outside of the museum at the end of the tour.
Very very hard for walking visitor. No way to walk to the entrance. And there isn't any public traffic way to arrive here. You have to driving yourself. Very worse experience

How much you enjoy your visit will really depend on how in tune you are with the history surrounding the place. The fort is not much, as most of the original has been destroyed. The museum is not bad, and is one of the few which cover the end of Imperial China.
There is not much left of the original fort. But the museum is very well done. Well worth the visit
If you love history, especially Chinese history then you might enjoy paying this site a visit.

data.formatted_address: Citizens Plaza, 86 1st Avenue, Tianjin, 滨海新区 China, 300456
data.name: Holiday Inn Binhai Tianjin

reviews.text: One the of more interesting building designs, in a city with a lot of fresh architectural designs, this Holiday Inn really stands out.  Shaped like a pyramid that leans forward on one edge, this steel & glass structure is pleasing to the eye.  Rooms are spacious and we'll maintained.  I've stayed here many times & find it's a good location when on business in Tianjin  ( TEDA ). Helpful staff when you need them who speak passable English.   Fast Internet, too.

Helpful staff, especially the guys at reception. The room was clean and cozy. I was dissatisfied with the bar/live music area, as it was quite expensive, had a stiff atmosphere, all-chinese music with the same musicians every day, and staff wouldn't let me finish my whiskey in my room - just stay away from that area. Location is OK, with plenty of shopping malls nearby.

I am a Singaporean now living in France.  Have been a business traveler for 30 years and having stayed in uncountable hotels world wide and tens of hotels all over China.  I have stayed here for 3 weeks, checking out today, and there is no doubt  that this is the best hotel I have ever stayed.in China.  I do not normally write a review or recommendation letter but this hotel, especially the service staff - from duty managers to F & B outlets to conceirge - impressed me so much that I have written a recommendation letter to the H.R. to praise 7 staff members for their excellent service.

Thanks to all the staff members in Holiday Inn Bin Hai for making my 3-week stay a very pleasant and comfortable one and I will definitely  choose to stay in this hotel again if I return to Tianjin, China in the future.
It's a very good and warm place to stay the hotel management is super supportive and will help you for a wonderful stay if your inTEDA next time please go for it
Decent room and good facilities.
